name: Prometheus
desc: Deploy Prometheus to monitor and alert on the performance and reliability of your systems and applications. Prometheus is an open-source systems monitoring and alerting toolkit designed for reliability and scalability.
longDesc:
Prometheus is a powerful open-source monitoring solution that collects metrics from configured targets at specified intervals, evaluates rule expressions, and triggers alerts if certain conditions are met. It is widely used for monitoring microservices and cloud-native environments.

**Key Features:**
- **One-Click Deployment:** Easily set up Prometheus using Docker or Kubernetes for rapid installation and configuration.
- **Scalability:** Capable of handling millions of time series data points, making it suitable for large-scale environments.
- **Privacy and Security:** Collects metrics without storing sensitive data, enhancing security during monitoring.
- **API Compatibility:** Provides a powerful HTTP API for querying and retrieving metrics, enabling integration with various tools and dashboards.
- **Flexible Data Model:** Supports multidimensional data collection with time series data, allowing users to slice and dice metrics according to their needs.
useCases:
- **DevOps Teams:** Monitor application performance, server health, and system resource usage, enabling proactive incident management.
- **Enterprises:** Implement Prometheus to ensure the reliability and performance of services, particularly in microservices architectures.
- **Educators:** Use Prometheus in courses focused on monitoring, cloud computing, and DevOps practices.
support:
- **Community Forums:** Engage with the Prometheus community for support and discussions through the [Prometheus Users Mailing List](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/prometheus-users) and [Prometheus GitHub Repository](https://github.com/prometheus/prometheus).
- **Documentation:** Comprehensive guides and user manuals are available at the [Prometheus Documentation](https://prometheus.io/docs/) for detailed reference.
- **Troubleshooting Help:** Access the issues section on GitHub to report bugs and find community-contributed solutions.

This template provides an overview of Prometheusâ€™s functionalities and practical applications, emphasizing its importance in monitoring and alerting. For more detailed information, visit the [official Prometheus website](https://prometheus.io/).

options.name: alertmanager.checkConfig
options.desc: Check configuration with amtool check-config. The call to amtool is subject to sandboxing by Nix. If you use credentials stored in external files (environmentFile, etc), they will not be visible to amtool and it will report errors, despite a correct configuration.

options.name: alertmanager.clusterPeers
options.desc: Initial peers for HA cluster.

options.name: alertmanager.configText
options.desc: Alertmanager configuration as YAML text. If non-null, this option defines the text that is written to alertmanager.yml. If null, the contents of alertmanager.yml is generated from the structured config options.

options.name: alertmanager.configuration
options.desc: Alertmanager configuration as nix attribute set.

options.name: alertmanager.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Prometheus Alertmanager.

options.name: alertmanager.environmentFile
options.desc: File to load as environment file. Environment variables from this file will be interpolated into the config file using envsubst with this syntax: $ENVIRONMENT ${VARIABLE}

options.name: alertmanager.extraFlags
options.desc: Extra commandline options when launching the Alertmanager.

options.name: alertmanager.listenAddress
options.desc: Address to listen on for the web interface and API. Empty string will listen on all interfaces. “localhost” will listen on 127.0.0.1 (but not ::1).

options.name: alertmanager.logFormat
options.desc: If set use a syslog logger or JSON logging.

options.name: alertmanager.logLevel
options.desc: Only log messages with the given severity or above.

options.name: alertmanager.openFirewall
options.desc: Open port in firewall for incoming connections.

options.name: alertmanager.package
options.desc: The prometheus-alertmanager package to use.

options.name: alertmanager.port
options.desc: Port to listen on for the web interface and API.
options.type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: alertmanager.webExternalUrl
options.desc: The URL under which Alertmanager is externally reachable (for example, if Alertmanager is served via a reverse proxy). Used for generating relative and absolute links back to Alertmanager itself. If the URL has a path portion, it will be used to prefix all HTTP endoints served by Alertmanager. If omitted, relevant URL components will be derived automatically.

options.name: alertmanagerIrcRelay.enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Alertmanager IRC Relay.

options.name: alertmanagerIrcRelay.extraFlags
options.desc: Extra command line options to pass to alertmanager-irc-relay.

options.name: alertmanagerIrcRelay.package
options.desc: The alertmanager-irc-relay package to use.

options.name: alertmanagerIrcRelay.settings
options.desc: Configuration for Alertmanager IRC Relay as a Nix attribute set. For a reference, check out the example configuration and the source code. Note: The webhook’s URL MUST point to the IRC channel where the message should be posted. For #mychannel from the example, this would be http://localhost:8080/mychannel.

options.name: alertmanagerNotificationQueueCapacity
options.desc: The capacity of the queue for pending alert manager notifications.

options.name: alertmanagerWebhookLogger.enable

options.name: alertmanagers
options.desc: A list of alertmanagers to send alerts to. See the official documentation for more information.

options.name: checkConfig
options.desc: Check configuration with promtool check. The call to promtool is subject to sandboxing by Nix. If you use credentials stored in external files (password_file, bearer_token_file, etc), they will not be visible to promtool and it will report errors, despite a correct configuration. To resolve this, you may set this option to syntax-only in order to only syntax check the Prometheus configuration.

options.name: configText
options.desc: If non-null, this option defines the text that is written to prometheus.yml. If null, the contents of prometheus.yml is generated from the structured config options.

options.name: enable
options.desc: Whether to enable Prometheus monitoring daemon.

options.name: enableAgentMode
options.desc: Whether to enable agent mode.

options.name: enableReload
options.desc: Reload prometheus when configuration file changes (instead of restart). The following property holds: switching to a configuration (switch-to-configuration) that changes the prometheus configuration only finishes successfully when prometheus has finished loading the new configuration.

options.desc: Path under which the stats socket is placed. The user/group under which the exporter runs, should be able to access the socket in order to scrape the metrics successfully. Please keep in mind that the stats module has changed in Dovecot 2.3+ which is not compatible with this exporter. The following extra config has to be passed to Dovecot to ensure that recent versions work with this exporter: {  services.prometheus.exporters.dovecot.enable = true;  services.prometheus.exporters.dovecot.socketPath = "/var/run/dovecot2/old-stats";  services.dovecot2.mailPlugins.globally.enable = [ "old_stats" ];  services.dovecot2.extraConfig = ''   service old-stats {    unix_listener old-stats {     user = dovecot-exporter     group = dovecot-exporter     mode = 0660    }    fifo_listener old-stats-mail {     mode = 0660     user = dovecot     group = dovecot    }    fifo_listener old-stats-user {     mode = 0660     user = dovecot     group = dovecot    }   }   plugin {    old_stats_refresh = 30 secs    old_stats_track_cmds = yes   }  ''; }

options.desc: Path under which to expose metrics.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.honor_labels
options.desc: Controls how Prometheus handles conflicts between labels that are already present in scraped data and labels that Prometheus would attach server-side (“job” and “instance” labels, manually configured target labels, and labels generated by service discovery implementations). If honor_labels is set to “true”, label conflicts are resolved by keeping label values from the scraped data and ignoring the conflicting server-side labels. If honor_labels is set to “false”, label conflicts are resolved by renaming conflicting labels in the scraped data to “exported_<original-label>” (for example “exported_instance”, “exported_job”) and then attaching server-side labels. This is useful for use cases such as federation, where all labels specified in the target should be preserved. Defaults to false in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.honor_timestamps
options.desc: honor_timestamps controls whether Prometheus respects the timestamps present in scraped data. If honor_timestamps is set to true, the timestamps of the metrics exposed by the target will be used. If honor_timestamps is set to false, the timestamps of the metrics exposed by the target will be ignored. Defaults to true in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.kubernetes_sd_configs.*.selectors
options.desc: Optional label and field selectors to limit the discovery process to a subset of available resources. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/field-selectors/ and https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/working-with-objects/labels/ to learn more about the possible filters that can be used. Endpoints role supports pod, service and endpoints selectors, other roles only support selectors matching the role itself (e.g. node role can only contain node selectors). Note: When making decision about using field/label selector make sure that this is the best approach - it will prevent Prometheus from reusing single list/watch for all scrape configs. This might result in a bigger load on the Kubernetes API, because per each selector combination there will be additional LIST/WATCH. On the other hand, if you just want to monitor small subset of pods in large cluster it’s recommended to use selectors. Decision, if selectors should be used or not depends on the particular situation.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.nerve_sd_configs.*.paths
options.desc: Paths can point to a single service, or the root of a tree of services.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.nerve_sd_configs.*.servers
options.desc: The Zookeeper servers.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.nerve_sd_configs.*.timeout
options.desc: Timeout value. Defaults to 10s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs
options.desc: List of OpenStack service discovery configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.all_tenants
options.desc: Whether the service discovery should list all instances for all projects. It is only relevant for the ‘instance’ role and usually requires admin permissions. Defaults to false in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.application_credential_id
options.desc: The application_credential_id or application_credential_name fields are required if using an application credential to authenticate. Some providers allow you to create an application credential to authenticate rather than a password.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.application_credential_name
options.desc: The application_credential_id or application_credential_name fields are required if using an application credential to authenticate. Some providers allow you to create an application credential to authenticate rather than a password.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.application_credential_secret
options.desc: The application_credential_secret field is required if using an application credential to authenticate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.availability
options.desc: The availability of the endpoint to connect to. Must be one of public, admin or internal. Defaults to public in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.domain_id
options.desc: At most one of domain_id and domain_name must be provided if using username with Identity V3. Otherwise, either are optional.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.domain_name
options.desc: At most one of domain_id and domain_name must be provided if using username with Identity V3. Otherwise, either are optional.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.identity_endpoint
options.desc: identity_endpoint specifies the HTTP endpoint that is required to work with the Identity API of the appropriate version. While it’s ultimately needed by all of the identity services, it will often be populated by a provider-level function.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.password
options.desc: password for the Identity V2 and V3 APIs. Consult with your provider’s control panel to discover your account’s preferred method of authentication.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.port
options.desc: The port to scrape metrics from. If using the public IP address, this must instead be specified in the relabeling rule. Defaults to 80 in prometheus when set to null.
options.type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.project_id
options.desc: The project_id and project_name fields are optional for the Identity V2 API. Some providers allow you to specify a project_name instead of the project_id. Some require both. Your provider’s authentication policies will determine how these fields influence authentication.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.project_name
options.desc: The project_id and project_name fields are optional for the Identity V2 API. Some providers allow you to specify a project_name instead of the project_id. Some require both. Your provider’s authentication policies will determine how these fields influence authentication.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.refresh_interval
options.desc: Refresh interval to re-read the instance list. Defaults to 60s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.region
options.desc: The OpenStack Region.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.role
options.desc: The OpenStack role of entities that should be discovered.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config
options.desc: TLS configuration.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config.ca_file
options.desc: CA certificate to validate API server certificate with.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config.cert_file
options.desc: Certificate file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config.insecure_skip_verify
options.desc: Disable validation of the server certificate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config.key_file
options.desc: Key file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.tls_config.server_name
options.desc: ServerName extension to indicate the name of the server. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.userid
options.desc: username is required if using Identity V2 API. Consult with your provider’s control panel to discover your account’s username. In Identity V3, either userid or a combination of username and domain_id or domain_name are needed.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.openstack_sd_configs.*.username
options.desc: username is required if using Identity V2 API. Consult with your provider’s control panel to discover your account’s username. In Identity V3, either userid or a combination of username and domain_id or domain_name are needed.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.params
options.desc: Optional HTTP URL parameters.
options.type: null or (attribute set of list of string)

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.proxy_url
options.desc: Optional proxy URL.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs
options.desc: List of PuppetDB service discovery configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.authorization
options.desc: Optional Authorization header configuration.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.authorization.credentials
options.desc: Sets the credentials. It is mutually exclusive with credentials_file.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.authorization.credentials_file
options.desc: Sets the credentials to the credentials read from the configured file. It is mutually exclusive with credentials.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.authorization.type
options.desc: Sets the authentication type. Defaults to Bearer in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.basic_auth
options.desc: Optional HTTP basic authentication information.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.basic_auth.password
options.desc: HTTP password

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.basic_auth.password_file
options.desc: HTTP password file

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.basic_auth.username
options.desc: HTTP username

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.follow_redirects
options.desc: Configure whether HTTP requests follow HTTP 3xx redirects. Defaults to true in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.include_parameters
options.desc: Whether to include the parameters as meta labels. Due to the differences between parameter types and Prometheus labels, some parameters might not be rendered. The format of the parameters might also change in future releases. Note: Enabling this exposes parameters in the Prometheus UI and API. Make sure that you don’t have secrets exposed as parameters if you enable this. Defaults to false in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2
options.desc: Optional OAuth 2.0 configuration. Cannot be used at the same time as basic_auth or authorization.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.client_id
options.desc: OAuth client ID.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.client_secret
options.desc: OAuth client secret.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.client_secret_file
options.desc: Read the client secret from a file. It is mutually exclusive with client_secret.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.endpoint_params
options.desc: Optional parameters to append to the token URL.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.scopes
options.desc: Scopes for the token request.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.oauth2.token_url
options.desc: The URL to fetch the token from.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.port
options.desc: The port to scrape metrics from. Defaults to 80 in prometheus when set to null.
options.type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.proxy_url
options.desc: Optional proxy URL.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.query
options.desc: Puppet Query Language (PQL) query. Only resources are supported. https://puppet.com/docs/puppetdb/latest/api/query/v4/pql.html

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.refresh_interval
options.desc: Refresh interval to re-read the resources list. Defaults to 60s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config
options.desc: TLS configuration.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config.ca_file
options.desc: CA certificate to validate API server certificate with.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config.cert_file
options.desc: Certificate file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config.insecure_skip_verify
options.desc: Disable validation of the server certificate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config.key_file
options.desc: Key file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.tls_config.server_name
options.desc: ServerName extension to indicate the name of the server. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.puppetdb_sd_configs.*.url
options.desc: The URL of the PuppetDB root query endpoint.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs
options.desc: List of relabel configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.action
options.desc: Action to perform based on regex matching. Defaults to replace in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.modulus
options.desc: Modulus to take of the hash of the source label values.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.regex
options.desc: Regular expression against which the extracted value is matched. Defaults to (.*) in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.replacement
options.desc: Replacement value against which a regex replace is performed if the regular expression matches. Defaults to $1 in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.separator
options.desc: Separator placed between concatenated source label values. Defaults to ; in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.source_labels
options.desc: The source labels select values from existing labels. Their content is concatenated using the configured separator and matched against the configured regular expression.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.relabel_configs.*.target_label
options.desc: Label to which the resulting value is written in a replace action. It is mandatory for replace actions.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.sample_limit
options.desc: Per-scrape limit on number of scraped samples that will be accepted. If more than this number of samples are present after metric relabelling the entire scrape will be treated as failed. 0 means no limit. Defaults to 0 in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs
options.desc: List of Scaleway service discovery configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.access_key
options.desc: Access key to use. https://console.scaleway.com/project/credentials

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.api_url
options.desc: API URL to use when doing the server listing requests. Defaults to https://api.scaleway.com in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.follow_redirects
options.desc: Configure whether HTTP requests follow HTTP 3xx redirects. Defaults to true in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.name_filter
options.desc: Specify a name filter (works as a LIKE) to apply on the server listing request.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.port
options.desc: The port to scrape metrics from. Defaults to 80 in prometheus when set to null.
options.type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.project_id
options.desc: Project ID of the targets.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.proxy_url
options.desc: Optional proxy URL.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.refresh_interval
options.desc: Refresh interval to re-read the managed targets list. Defaults to 60s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.role
options.desc: Role of the targets to retrieve. Must be instance or baremetal.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.secret_key
options.desc: Secret key to use when listing targets. https://console.scaleway.com/project/credentials It is mutually exclusive with secret_key_file.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.secret_key_file
options.desc: Sets the secret key with the credentials read from the configured file. It is mutually exclusive with secret_key.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tags_filter
options.desc: Specify a tag filter (a server needs to have all defined tags to be listed) to apply on the server listing request.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config
options.desc: TLS configuration.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config.ca_file
options.desc: CA certificate to validate API server certificate with.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config.cert_file
options.desc: Certificate file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config.insecure_skip_verify
options.desc: Disable validation of the server certificate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config.key_file
options.desc: Key file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.tls_config.server_name
options.desc: ServerName extension to indicate the name of the server. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scaleway_sd_configs.*.zone
options.desc: Zone is the availability zone of your targets (e.g. fr-par-1). Defaults to fr-par-1 in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scheme
options.desc: The URL scheme with which to fetch metrics from targets. Defaults to http in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scrape_interval
options.desc: How frequently to scrape targets from this job. Defaults to the globally configured default.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.scrape_timeout
options.desc: Per-target timeout when scraping this job. Defaults to the globally configured default.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.serverset_sd_configs
options.desc: List of Zookeeper Serverset service discovery configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.serverset_sd_configs.*.paths
options.desc: Paths can point to a single service, or the root of a tree of services.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.serverset_sd_configs.*.servers
options.desc: The Zookeeper servers.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.serverset_sd_configs.*.timeout
options.desc: Timeout value. Defaults to 10s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.static_configs
options.desc: List of labeled target groups for this job.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.static_configs.*.labels
options.desc: Labels assigned to all metrics scraped from the targets.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.static_configs.*.targets
options.desc: The targets specified by the target group.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.target_limit
options.desc: Per-scrape config limit on number of unique targets that will be accepted. If more than this number of targets are present after target relabeling, Prometheus will mark the targets as failed without scraping them. 0 means no limit. This is an experimental feature, this behaviour could change in the future. Defaults to 0 in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config
options.desc: Configures the scrape request’s TLS settings.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config.ca_file
options.desc: CA certificate to validate API server certificate with.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config.cert_file
options.desc: Certificate file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config.insecure_skip_verify
options.desc: Disable validation of the server certificate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config.key_file
options.desc: Key file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.tls_config.server_name
options.desc: ServerName extension to indicate the name of the server. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs
options.desc: List of Triton Serverset service discovery configurations.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.account
options.desc: The account to use for discovering new targets.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.dns_suffix
options.desc: The DNS suffix which should be applied to target.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.endpoint
options.desc: The Triton discovery endpoint (e.g. cmon.us-east-3b.triton.zone). This is often the same value as dns_suffix.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.groups
options.desc: A list of groups for which targets are retrieved, only supported when targeting the container role. If omitted all containers owned by the requesting account are scraped.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.port
options.desc: The port to use for discovery and metric scraping. Defaults to 9163 in prometheus when set to null.
options.type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.refresh_interval
options.desc: The interval which should be used for refreshing targets. Defaults to 60s in prometheus when set to null.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.role
options.desc: The type of targets to discover, can be set to:  “container” to discover virtual machines (SmartOS zones, lx/KVM/bhyve branded zones) running on Triton “cn” to discover compute nodes (servers/global zones) making up the Triton infrastructure  Defaults to container in prometheus when set to null.

options.desc: Certificate file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.tls_config.insecure_skip_verify
options.desc: Disable validation of the server certificate.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.tls_config.key_file
options.desc: Key file for client cert authentication to the server.

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.tls_config.server_name
options.desc: ServerName extension to indicate the name of the server. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1

options.name: scrapeConfigs.*.triton_sd_configs.*.version
options.desc: The Triton discovery API version. Defaults to 1 in prometheus when set to null.
